title: 114_hr2489
content: The Act titled "Dam Rehabilitation and Repair Act of 2015" focuses on the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a definition of a "deficient dam" as a dam that fails to meet minimum safety standards and poses a risk to the public. The term 'publicly-owned dam' refers to a dam owned by State, local, municipal, or tribal governments, including those owned by nonprofit organizations providing public benefits like flood control districts, public water utilities, and irrigation districts. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a definition of "rehabilitation" as repair, replacement, reconstruction, or removal of a dam to meet state or tribal dam safety standards. Additionally, a program for the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams is added after section 8 of the Act. The National Dam Safety Program Act is amended to include a definition of "rehabilitation" as repair, replacement, reconstruction, or removal of a dam to meet state or tribal dam safety standards. A program for the rehabilitation and repair of deficient dams is added after section 8 of the Act. The Administrator will establish a program within FEMA to provide grant assistance to States for rehabilitating publicly-owned deficient dams. States interested in grants can submit applications meeting specified requirements. Grants may be awarded for the rehabilitation of deficient dams to eligible States. The Administrator will provide grant assistance to States for rehabilitating deficient dams. States can apply for grants to rehabilitate dams, and the Administrator will enter into project grant agreements with eligible States. States must provide assurance for maintenance of the dam during its expected life. The Administrator will provide grant assistance to States for rehabilitating deficient dams. States may enter agreements with Indian tribes to transfer grant funds for dam rehabilitation. Recipients of grants must comply with set standards. The Administrator will develop a risk-based priority system for identifying deficient dams eligible for grants. Funds allocated for grants to States will be divided equally among applying States and based on the number of non-Federal publicly-owned dams. The funds provided under this section cannot be used to rehabilitate Federal dams, perform routine maintenance, modify dams for hydroelectric power, or increase water storage capacity. The Federal share of the cost of rehabilitating a deficient dam under this section cannot exceed 75 percent. States receiving grants must require contracts for various services to be awarded in a specific manner. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2016, $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2017, $150,000,000 for fiscal year 2018, $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2019, and $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2020. Authorization of Appropriations: $250,000,000 for fiscal year 2020. Additional staff funding of $400,000 for FEMA for fiscal years 2016-2020. Rulemaking required by FEMA Administrator within specified timeframes. The Administrator of FEMA must issue a final rule for the amendments within a specified timeframe after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 15. BUY AMERICA is added to the National Dam Safety Program Act, emphasizing the Buy America provision. The Buy America provision in the National Dam Safety Program Act requires that steel, iron, and manufactured goods for projects must be produced in the United States, with exceptions that can be granted by the Administrator. The Administrator can waive the Buy America provision requirements if it is in the public interest, if the materials are not available in the US, or if using US materials increases project costs by more than 25 percent. The Administrator can waive Buy America provision requirements if it is in the public interest or if materials are unavailable in the US. Requests for waivers must be submitted with required information. Regulations will be issued to determine inconsistency with public interest. The Administrator must provide notice and an opportunity for public comment on waiver requests at least 30 days before making a decision. The notice must include information on the request and be provided electronically on FEMA's official website. The Administrator must publish a detailed justification in the Federal Register for any waiver issued under subsection (b), addressing public comments received. An annual report specifying projects for which waivers were issued must be submitted to relevant committees. The Administrator must publish a detailed justification in the Federal Register for any waiver issued under subsection (b), addressing public comments received. An annual report specifying projects for which waivers were issued must be submitted to relevant committees. The report must identify the country of origin and product specifications for steel, iron, or manufactured goods acquired under each waiver, summarize the monetary value of contracts awarded, provide justification for each waiver, and detail funds expended on U.S. produced goods for projects. The Administrator must justify any waiver issued under subsection (b) in the Federal Register, detailing public comments received. An annual report listing projects with waivers must be submitted to committees, specifying the origin and specifications of steel, iron, or goods acquired, contract values, waiver justifications, and funds spent on U.S. produced goods. The report also includes an employment impact analysis of waivers on manufacturing jobs in the U.S. The Administrator cannot impose limitations on state requirements for projects funded under this Act, allowing states to have stricter rules on the use of foreign materials. Intentional violations may result in ineligibility for contracts funded by this Act. The Administrator or a court can determine intentional misuse of 'Made in America' labels on non-U.S. steel, iron, or goods in projects covered by this section. Representing non-U.S. goods as U.S.-made can lead to penalties. This section must align with U.S. international agreements. The Administrator must ensure that projects funded under this Act use steel, iron, and manufactured goods from countries that comply with international agreements. If a foreign country violates an agreement by discriminating against U.S.-made goods, the Administrator will prohibit their use in projects. An emergency waiver provision is also included. The Administrator may waive the applicability of the section in an emergency.
